Graphical abstract This review summarizes in-situ electrocatalyst reconstruction in electrocatalytic H2 evolution, and CO2 and N2 reduction, focusing on the correlations between reconfigured surface and performance. Cathodic electrocatalytic reactions, such as hydrogen evolution and CO2/N2 reduction, are the key processes that store intermittent electricity into stable chemical energy. Although a great progress has been made to boost activity and selectivity via elaborative catalyst design, the structure–property relationships have not been sufficiently understood in the context of surface reconfiguration under working conditions. Recent efforts devoted to tracking dynamic evolution of electrocatalysts using in-situ and/or operando techniques gave new insights into the real structure and working mechanism of active sites, and provided principles to design better catalysts. The achievement of cathodic electrocatalysts in this subject is herein summarized, focusing on the correlations between reconstructed surface and electrocatalytic performance. Briefly, the thermodynamics of reconstruction at cathodes is discussed at first, and then the representative progresses in H2 evolution and CO2/N2 reduction are introduced in sequence to acquire insights into electrochemical processes on in-situ reconfigured surfaces or interfaces. Finally, a perspective is offered to guide future investigations. This review is anticipated to shed some new light on in-depth understanding cathodic electrocatalysis and exploiting prominent electrocatalysts. Keywords Hydrogen evolution reaction CO2 reduction reaction Nitrogen reduction reaction In-situ reconstruction Electronic configurations Valence states Topological changes 1 Introduction Global energy and environmental challenge due to the over-consumption of fossil fuels is spawning an urgent demand for developing economical, efficient and eco-friendly energy conversion systems [1]. Various electrochemical technologies such as fuel cells, water electrolysis, CO2/N2 reduction, etc., have attracted extensive interest from basic and practical perspectives [2–4]. In these systems, cathodic reduction reactions produce value-added chemicals, e.g., H2 from water electrolysis, and multi-carbon products from CO2 electrochemical reduction, which serve as the key routes to store intermittent electricity into stable chemical energy [5,6]. Atomic-level understanding on active-site structures is a matter of great concern to reveal catalytic mechanisms and to further exploit high-performance catalysts. However, electrocatalysts may undergo dynamic changes of valence states and surface topology during operations at a certain potential [7], which unfortunately causes a great challenge to understand the structure–activity relationships [8]. The most vital issue is in-situ/operando monitoring catalyst reconstruction and identifying the working state of electrocatalyst surface [9,10]. In comparison with well-documented surface oxidation/reconstruction in oxygen evolution/reduction reactions (OER/ORR) at highly positive potentials [11 –16], the dynamic changes of catalysts in cathodic electrocatalysis, e.g., hydrogen evolution reaction (HER), CO2 reduction reaction (CO2RR) and N2 reduction reaction (NRR), have not caught enough attentions. A quite amount of studies manifested the unchanged surface according to the consistent chemical status characterized before and after electrochemical tests, however questions are still remained in the regard of time- and spatial-mismatches between the dynamic changes and the used spectroscopies. With the deepening of research, in-situ and/or operando techniques are taken to track reconstruction, capture dynamic structure, and analyze real-time working state of electrocatalysts [9]. Recent progresses highlight the universality and importance of electrocatalyst reconstruction during cathodic processes, which produces real active-sites toward efficient electrocatalysis and diverse catalytic mechanisms. For instance, initial CuO x electrocatalysts in CO2RR would be reduced to new active species of Cu(0)/Cu(I) with distinct activity in a few minutes [17]. Transition-metal dichalcogenides (TMDs), as the electrocatalyst for HER, have demonstrated an activation period (oxidation or reduction) toward enhanced performance [18 –20]. Sometimes, in-situ reconstructions have negative impacts on the long-term stability of electrocatalysts, such as activity loss due to reshaping Cu in CO2RR [17]. Understanding and regulating such in-situ surface evolution are of both fundamental and practical interest [21]. Following the recent achievements, it’s necessary to propose a comprehensive, authoritative, critical, and readable review that can clarify the key issues for the refactoring of cathodic catalysts (e.g., driving force, dynamic configurations, microscopic kinetics, etc.), and further guide the design of better catalysts. However, present review papers devoted the relevant concerns to a specific reaction (e.g., CO2RR) or a kind of catalysts (e.g., Cu) [17,22], losing the comprehensive view over cathodic electrocatalysis. Meanwhile, some focusing on in-situ/operando techniques lacked in-depth understanding of dynamic changes and mechanisms associated with working conditions (e.g., applied potentials, electrolytes, intermediates, etc.) [9,23,24]. This review aims to contribute an overview of in-situ catalyst reconstruction in cathodic electrocatalysis (Fig. 1 ), with a particular emphasis on the key issues such as driving force, dynamic configurations, microscopic kinetics, etc. It at first discusses the thermodynamic fundamentals of surface reconstruction at cathodes, and then summarizes the current status and recent advances in understanding the reconstruction and (de)activation of catalysts in cathodic HER, CO2RR, and NRR. Accordingly, some strategies to direct or inhibit the structural reconstruction are introduced for boosting electrocatalytic performance. Finally, a perspectives is included and anticipated to inspire future investigations. It seeks to provide insights into refactoring principles, working state of real active-sites and electrocatalytic mechanisms, and to guide the ingenious design of high-performance catalysts. 2 Fundamentals of self-reconstruction at cathodes Generally, cathodic reductions toward fuels or value-added chemicals use electrons as the reductant at a negative potential, which makes a thermodynamically non-spontaneous process happen because the applied electro-field elevates the free energy of the reactant-side with electrons (Fig. 2 a). In comparison with heating that synchronously uplifts both reactants and products in thermocatalysis, an applied bias with directional features can vary the energy state of the reactant-side alone, making subversive alteration to thermodynamic relationship [25]. In this regard, ambient-stable electrodes or electrocatalysts become reactive when a bias is applied, and their in-situ reconstruction should be concerned about. At the condition with an electrochemical bias applied, the structural reconstruction of catalysts mainly includes the changes of valence states and surface topology. The former includes the reduction/oxidation of electrocatalysts relying on applied potentials, and the concomitant changes of composition and phase. For instance, Cu oxides are reduced to metallic Cu species with reshaped nanostructures during CO2RR [17], and Ni is easy oxidized to hydroxides in alkaline HER [26]. By contrast, the latter emphasizes the reconfiguration of surface nanostructures (i.e., roughness, porosity, crystallinity and crystal planes) even in the absence of redox processes [7], where the strong interactions between surface atoms and reaction intermediates evidently alter the interface energy of catalysts and drive the changes. For example, in-situ alteration of facet-distribution was observed on Cu polycrystalline and nanocrystals in CO2RR owing to the strong surface bindings with *CO and *H intermediates [27,28]. In view of valence-state changes, the relevant thermodynamic fundamentals should be examined at first. Herein, we take HER and CO2RR as examples to discuss the thermodynamic states of electrocatalysts at working potentials. Ni and Cu based materials are analyzed as the models, regarding their wide use in HER and CO2RR, respectively. As for the HER at an acidic condition ([H+] = 1.0 M), the potential of a reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) is 0 V vs. a standard hydrogen electrode (SHE) [φ0(H+/H2)], and a potential window of 0 ∼ -0.4 V (vs. SHE) is usually adopted to evaluate electrocatalysts because of overpotentials that are requisite to overcome the kinetic barrier of HER (Fig. 2b). The φ0(Ni2+/Ni) of −0.23 V vs. SHE falls in this range, indicating the possible in-situ reduction or oxidation of Ni species with the regard of ubiquitous kinetic barriers. In an alkaline solution ([OH–] = 1.0 M), the φ0(Ni(OH)2/Ni) is −0.68 V vs. SHE, higher than φ0(H2O/H2) (-0.83 V vs. SHE), which implies a thermodynamically-favored reduction toward metallic Ni. However, on the solid–liquid interfaces of a working electrocatalyst, the real thermodynamics is quite different from the standard one owing to the deviation of reactant concentrations [29,30]. For example, the extensively increased [OH–] in an electrical double layer due to fast H2 evolution not only alters the thermodynamics subversively [31,32], but also enables the strong binding of *OH with oxophilic Ni atoms, leading to a huge kinetic barrier toward in-situ reduction. To some extent, these factors can make the oxidation of Ni favorable, mainly relying on testing conditions. Owing to the uncertainty of thermodynamics in a specific research, the identification on electrocatalyst reconstruction in HER requires systematic in-situ or operando monitoring. By contrast, CO2RR is conducted at more negative potentials that easily drive the in-situ reduction of Cu oxides or hydroxides [33]. In a typical electrolyte of 0.5 M KHCO3 (pH ∼ 7.5), the potential for Cu(OH)2 reduction to Cu is 0.082 V (vs. SHE). Usually, a potential range of −0.2 ∼ -1.0 V vs. RHE is adopted for tests, which means a largely negative potential (-0.584 ∼ -1.384 V vs. SHE) imposed on Cu(OH)2, enabling its quite thermodynamic-favored reduction to Cu (Fig. 2b). As previously indicated, the in-situ reduction of Cu-based electrocatalysts is prevailing along with CO2RR [34]. This is different from the case of HER because of its more negative potentials applied on electrodes. As the other kind of reconfiguration, changes of surface topology show obvious dependence on working conditions. Although electrocatalysts are in their low-valance states, they still suffer from detectable reconstructions owing to the changes of micro-environment and thermodynamic on electrodes during electrocatalysis. This phenomenon has been reported in CO2RR [17,34]. The redox of metallic Cu electrocatalysts is thermodynamically disfavored, but the reconstructions of morphology (e.g., roughness, porosity, facet redistribution, microstructures, etc.) occur when the bindings with reaction intermediates (e.g., *H and *CO) are strong enough to move surface atoms (Fig. 2c). In this case, the thermodynamic prediction on catalyst reconstruction is not enough, but in-situ/operando monitoring with a focus on the micro-environment on electrodes is more practically important. 3 Reconstruction in HER Over the past years, we have witnessed the rapid rise of noble-metal-free electrocatalysts explored for HER [35 –38], such as TMDs, transition-metal carbides (TMCs), transition-metal phosphides (TMPs), etc. Although prominent performance comparable to Pt has been achieved, the in-depth understanding on active surface that can experience in-situ reconstruction is still challenging. Herein, the reduction or oxidation of such cost-efficient electrocatalyts on site and the activity dependence on reconfigured surface are reviewed. 3.1 In-situ reduction As the typical one of TMDs electrocatalysts, nickel-based sulfides and selenides feature their abundant resources, high intrinsic activity and good electron transport capability [39,40]. The Ni element in such TMDs is at its high-valence state (+2 ∼ +3), with the possibility of reduction at cathodes during H2 evolution. Zheng and co-workers reported an activation period of two-dimensional NiS2 that finally converted into nanosheets with a visibly decreasing content of S. In 1.0 M KOH (Fig. 3 a), the reconfigured nanosheets afforded low overpotentials (η 10 and η 100) of only 67 and 161 mV to reach current densities of 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively [41]. X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) combined with electrochemical tests revealed that the in-situ generated Ni0, with a different coordination environment from those of NiS2 or Ni foil (Fig. 3b), served as catalytically active sites for the HER. The electrolyzer fabricated with NiS2-derived metallic Ni as the cathode and Fe-doped NiS2-derived hydroxide as the anode accomplished efficient overall water splitting with a cell voltage of 1.52 and 1.62 V to reach 10 and 100 mA cm−2, respectively (Fig. 3c). As inspired, they further proposed the electrochemical synthesis of ultrathin Ni nanosheets via in-situ reduction of 2D Ni-thiolate that was composed of interconnected square-planar [Ni-benzenedithiol (Ni-BDT)] motifs (Fig. 3d) [42]. The evolution to metallic Ni during the HER was confirmed by in-situ XAS analysis (Fig. 3e), along with a visible increase of HER activity (Fig. 3f). At a steady state, the reconstructed catalyst mainly consisted of Ni0 with a Ni(OH)2 thin layer, and exhibited comparable activity to that of commercial Pt/C (Fig. 3g). As an instructive example, these researches underline the interfacial reconstruction of reducible electrocatalysts and the significant contribution to boosting HER activity. As another one of TMDs electrocatalysts, CoSe2 has been extensively studied for both HER and OER [43]. At HER conditions, CoSe2 can undergo in-situ reduction to generate metallic Co active sites, which is similar to Ni-based TMDs. Chen and co-workers investigated the stability of P-substituted CoSe2 (CoSe1.26P1.42) under both HER and OER in 1.0 M KOH via liquid phase transmission electron microscopy (TEM), in-situ XAS and in-situ Raman spectroscopy [44]. The P-substitution generated vacancies or defects around Co cations in CoSe2, facilitating the structural transformation into “real active species” metallic Co during the HER. By contrast, the CoSe2 free-from P-doping was hardly reconstructed into Co. The effects on reconstruction by heteroatom doping were also evidenced in a large variety of electrocatalysts free from noble-metal elements. Wang and co-workers analyzed the surface compositions and oxidation states of cation (Fe)- and anion (S)-substituted CoP nanoparticles under electrochemical water-splitting conditions, to correlate activities with in-situ formed surface structure [46]. Fe-CoP underwent oxidation in an ambient condition to generate surface species of Fe-PO x and Co-PO x that restructured via different pathways owing to the varied reducibility. In the case of Fe0.5Co0.5P, Fe-PO x was more difficult to reduce than Co-PO x , and the remaining Fe-OH species on surface hampered the HER. By contrast, such surface oxides were able to be removed by a strong acid (e.g., 0.5 M H2SO4), re-exposing the active surface of CoP toward obviously boosted HER activity. In further view of metal carbides, the strong oxophilicity of early-transition-metal (e.g., Mo and W) makes their surface extremely easy to be oxidized [47], leading to carbide-oxide heterointerfaces that are still contentious in working state and mechanism. Recently, Gao and co-workers investigated Mo2C-MoO x as a model to unravel in-situ reconfiguration in acidic HER [45]. In-situ Raman spectroscopy demonstrated that surface Mo(VI) oxides were reduced to Mo(IV) species, along with a gradual increase of HER activity (Fig. 4 a and 4b). As ascertained by density function theory (DFT) calculations, the reduced surface with terminal Mo = O could bring the negative ΔG H* on bare Mo2C close to a thermodynamic neutral value, which surmounted the difficult H* desorption toward fast HER kinetics (Fig. 3c). The Mo2C-MoO x required a low η 10 of only 60 mV in 1.0 M HClO4, superior to Mo2C and the most of non-precious electrocatalysts. Similar reconfiguration was further evidenced on W2C-WO x . These findings have demonstrated the popular in-situ reduction of HER catalysts, in which heteroatom doping would boost the change thanks to the enriched structural defects and sometimes dopants on reconfigured surface could afford synergistic promotion for electrocatalysis. 3.2 In-situ oxidation The in-situ oxidation of electrocatalysts during HER relies on operation conditions, because the applied potentials to some extent overlap the redox potentials of elements involved. Wang and co-workers reported the in-situ oxidation of AuNi heterodimers toward NiO/Ni interfaces that promoted water dissociation, the sluggish step of alkaline HER, toward comparable HER activity with a Pt/C catalyst initially [26]. As surface Ni atoms were excessively oxidized, the AuNi unfortunately suffered deactivation in a long-term test, suggesting the interfacial synergy between NiO and Ni. Analogously, metal-phosphide@metal-hydroxide/oxyhydroxide core–shell catalysts were generated on NiCo2P x during a HER process, leading to the high activity in the beginning but the obvious decline later on [48]. To overcome the deterioration caused by excessive oxidation, a secondary component was introduced to increase oxygen resistance and enlarge electrochemical surface area. For example, Dai and co-workers discovered Cr2O3-blended NiO/Ni heterostructures as highly active HER catalysts with sustained H2 production over long operations (80 h) [49]. The Cr2O3 could maintain the NiO/Ni active sites from extensive oxidation and aggregation, owing to the formation of chemically inert NiCrO x during the HER. A suitable or controlled oxidation can serve as an effective electrochemical activation to enhance HER activity [50]. Xia and co-workers utilized an activation at 20 mA cm−2 for 10 h to produce a Co(OH) x @CoP hybrid that was robust and efficient for alkaline HER [51]. Such activation generated Co(OH) x species on the surface of CoP, boosting the capability of water dissociation, and thereby the overall HER kinetics. Similarly, Liu and co-workers reported the cathodic activation of V-doped Ni x S y to achieve obvious improvement in both activity and stability [20,52]. V-doped nickel sulfide transformed into Ni-V oxyhydroxides (NiOOH and VOOH) as new active species, and the V dopants promoted the intrinsic activity due to the rich electronic interactions between Ni and V. This coupling strategy was available for the doping by other group VB metals (Nb and Ta) that resulted in the similar activation on Ni sulfides, selenides, phosphides and oxides [52]. Similar situation was evidenced in Ni-Mo alloys, the state of the art noble-metal-free HER catalysts under alkaline conditions [53,54]. The potential for the evolution from Mo to MoO4 2- is more negative than that of H2 to H2O [55], enabling the oxidation and dissolution of Mo in Ni-Mo. Bau et al. identified the oxidation dissolution of NiMo into polymetallic anions that were further photo-deposited to amorphous MoO x under the sufficiently energetic light used in in-situ XAS and Raman measurements [56]. Such dissolution/re-deposition of Mo was further evidenced in Ni4Mo alloys and interpreted by Zhang and co-workers (Fig. 5 ) [57]. An activation process (∼4h) was visible in the chronoamperometry curves (top of Fig. 5a), accompanied with a detectable dissolution of Mo in the form of MoO4 2-. Interestingly, the stability got worse when the electrolyte was renewed every 1 h (bottom of Fig. 5a), but it recovered when extra MoO4 2- was injected, indicating a key role of the dissolved MoO4 2-. As further identified by in-situ Raman (Fig. 5b), MoO4 2- was re-adsorbed on the electrode surface and polymerized to Mo2O7 2- that was advantageous to weaken the strong *H binding on Ni sites and thereby to promote the alkaline HER, according to DFT calculation results (Fig. 5c). As inspired, a universal and facile strategy via adding appropriate MoO4 2- into electrolytes was proposed to enhance the HER activity of Ni4Mo alloy (Fig. 5d), as well as other electrocatalysts of single metal Ni, Fe, and Co. In a short summary, the reconstruction of electrocatalysts during a HER process include in-situ reduction and oxidation that are mainly associated with materials chemistry (e.g., redox thermodynamics, lattice dopants, structural defects, etc.) and operation conditions (e.g., potentials, electrolytes, pre-catalysts, etc.). Identifications on the reduction or oxidation of transition-metal electrocatalysts sometimes are still contentious, because in-situ reduced surface is easily oxidized when exposed to air [41]. Therefore, in-situ/operando monitoring, rather than ex-situ characterizations, is more convincing for understanding the configurations of a working surface. In most cases, the reconstruction was believed as a key step for an activation that led to gradually boosted activity [58,59]. A balance of reconstructed interfaces (e.g., NiO/Ni, Mo2C/MoOx, CoP/Co(OH)2, etc.) was the determinant to fulfil the synergistic enhancement on interfacial sites, which also pointed out the impacts on electrocatalyst stability because over-reaction species would impede the exposure of initial active sites and weaken their interfacial interactions. Moreover, efforts have been devoted to elaborately designing highly active HER electrocatalyts with excellent long-term durability via regulating or directing their surface reconstruction. 4 Reconstruction in CO2RR Owing to the dependence of CO2 reduction on the microscopic states of active sites, it is vital to identify the active components and their dynamic evolution during the reaction [60,61]. In this section, we will start with the reconstruction of Cu-based electrocatalysts that are extensively investigated for CO2RR, as well as the inspired strategies to improve activity and durability. Then, the similar trend of other candidates beyond Cu is introduced, highlighting the universal reconfigurations and available impacts on electrocatalysis. 4.1 Cu electrocatalysts Copper is one of the few metals that can electro-reduce CO2 to multi-carbon products with decent efficiencies [62 –64]. A momentous breakthrough in understanding catalytic performance has been achieved using in-situ/operando techniques. The structures and valence states of Cu surface dynamically changing in CO2RR could determine the distribution of reduction products [7]. Herein, we summarize the current status and recent advances of Cu, focusing on its in-situ reduction and surface reshaping. 4.1.1 Reconstruction focusing on valence states On account of the huge energy barrier for activating CO2 molecules, CO2RR requires a highly negative potential that easily leads to the reduction of Cu-based oxides/hydroxides toward metallic Cu. In comparison with pure metallic Cu, oxide/hydroxide-derived Cu (OD-Cu) usually affords superior performance, indicating the key roles of new-generated active sites on in-situ formed Cu nanograins [65,66]. When electro-polished Cu rich in Cu(0) was used as the catalyst, there were 16 products detected in CO2RR, with the quickly decreased Faradaic efficiency (FE) [67]. By contrast, OD-Cu could reach an FE more than 50% toward C2+ products [68 –70]. Regarding such in-situ reduction independent on the oxidation state and actual morphology of oxide/hydroxide precursors [71], we can have a hypothesis that the as-reduced surface configurations (e.g., nanostructures, valence states, exposed sites, roughness, etc.) are the determinant of electrocatalytic performance [61]. Han and co-workers fabricated two Cu-based electrodes with mixed valence states, namely, one containing Cu, Cu2O, and CuO via a heat–quench process (HQ-Cu) and the other one consisting of Cu and Cu(OH)2 via anodization (AN-Cu) [72]. At the steady stage of CO2RR, the electrodes were reduced to Cu(0), regardless of their initial states, suggesting the inapparent correlation between high C2+ selectivity and Cu oxidation states. As a model, the HQ-Cu clearly showed that oxide crystals were fragmented into irregular Cu nanograins at the applied negative potentials (Fig. 6 ), which facilitated C–C coupling toward enhanced C2+ selectivity [73]. Analogously, Grosse et al. identified the reduction of initially CuO x to Cu(0) on size-controlled Cu cubes [74]. The C-supported Cu cubes with 52% Cu2O were almost completely reduced with only 4.6% residual after CO2RR. Moreover, Hwang and co-workers showed that Cu2O in an initial size of 20 nm experienced not only reduction to metallic Cu but also fragmentation into 2 ∼ 4 nm small particles during CO2RR [69]. These nanoparticles were readily re-oxidized at open circuit potential inside of electrolytes, allowing labile Cu states. This can be used to explain the common detection of oxide species on spent Cu-based electrocatalysts via ex-situ characterizations. Although CuO x can be reduced to Cu during CO2RR, Cu(I) is an inevitable state that has recently demonstrated the benefit of generating C2+ products. Roldan Cuenya and co-workers found that the Cu(I) is difficult to be fully reduced during cathodic CO2RR [75], and Hwang’s group indicated that in-situ reduced Cu nanoparticles were more readily re-oxidized when a bias was withdrawn [69]. Apparently, particular attentions should be paid onto a Cu surface containing different amounts of Cu(I) and Cu(0). As been recently shown by Chou et al., the oxidation state distribution of Cu surface could correlate with the change of CO2RR mechanism [76]. Three model electrocatalysts of electrodeposited Cu, as-prepared Cu and CV-treated Cu (after 100 CV-treated cycles at CO2RR condition), representing the Cu(I), Cu(0) and Cu(I)/Cu(0) surfaces respectively, delivered the quite different product distribution (Fig. 7 a). The CV-treated Cu in particular featured more hydrocarbon products (FEC2H4 = 40% and FECH4 = 35%). In order to analyze the different CO species on Cu surface, they examined the in-situ surface-enhanced infrared absorption spectroscopy (SEIRAS) of the CV-treated Cu electrode (Fig. 7b). The intensity of the bridge-adsorbed CO (CObridge) associated peak reached a maximum in ∼30 min and remained at a holding potential of −0.9 V (Fig. 7c). In contrast, that of the atop-adsorbed CO (COatop) peak increased in the first 15 min and then decreased with time. According to the XAS that mainly exhibited the Cu(I) feature in the first 15 min, and completed changes from Cu(I) to Cu(0) for 60 min, they correlated the COatop and CObridge to the Cu(I) and Cu(0) sites, respectively. As depicted in Fig. 7(d), the COatop was obtained on the electrodeposited Cu surface with rich Cu(I), which was further reduced to C1 product such as CH4. But the strong CObridge was formed on Cu(0)-rich surface, inhibiting hydrocarbon formation. The CV-treated Cu electrode, containing the different amounts of Cu(I)/Cu(0), favored the coexistence of COatop and CObridge and thereby the high selectivity of ethylene. The spontaneous oxidation of Cu(0) under CO2RR working conditions was further proposed to interpret the co-existence of Cu(I) and Cu(0). Chen and co-workers investigated the dynamic oxidation state of Cu supported by Ag nanowires [77]. In-situ Raman identified the re-oxidation of Cu under cathodic potentials (Fig. 8 a). The characteristic T2g and T1u peaks of Cu2O obviously declined once the cathodic potential was applied in the first 2 min, but they remained steady at −0.55 V for 5 min, indicating that the Cu(I) cannot be completely reduced even though at a potential that could thermodynamically reduce Cu2O to Cu(0). Such a spontaneous re-oxidation (SRO) was ascribed to a trace amount of oxidative species in electrolyte, according to the obviously enhanced T2g and T1u peaks after O2 purging. There was a dynamic equilibrium between Cu(0) and Cu(l) at a mild negative potential, and such SRO was a competing reaction hindering the CO2RR (Fig. 8b). If it was faster than electroreduction, i.e., the surface Cu cannot be stabilized in Cu(0), the major product is CO. By contrast, once the SRO was slower, the stabilized Cu(0) and Cu(I) could undergo the CO2RR to produce hydrocarbons or alcohols. In an analogous system of Cu nanowires modified by Ag, they further unveiled a dynamic reconstruction from a phase-separated bimetallic structure into a Cu-Ag alloy [78], owing to a dynamic reoxidation-reduction cycle. The catalyst accomplished a CH4 FE of 60% (Fig. 8c), three times higher than that of primitive Cu nanowires. In-situ spectroscopies, including grazing-angle X-ray scattering/diffraction (GAXS), XAS and Raman, were conducted to uncover the atomic inter-diffusion process (Fig. 8d). Once exposed to the electrolyte, the Cu surface was spontaneously oxidized by oxidant species ([O]electrolyte, dissolved O2 or excessive OH– in-situ generated around electrode surface) into CuO x . At a mild cathodic potential (below − 0.35 V vs RHE), the SRO was dominated, resulting in a steady nonmetallic state. With a further increasing cathodic potential (−0.35 ∼ −0.55 V), more metallic Cu was produced, forming structural defects due to the removal of lattice oxygen. In a case with higher cathodic potentials (−0.55 ∼ −0.85 V), the reoxidation–reduction cycle was dominated by the reduction of Cu, and more structural defects were generated. This change facilitated the migration of both Ag and Cu atoms, boosting their alloying toward Cu-Ag. Such alloy was able to alleviate the SRO of metallic Cu, and more importantly induced a tensile strain with optimized d-band center, which could strengthen the *CHO binding for further reduction and simultaneously hinder the HER, resulting in the high selectivity of CH4. The control over the ratio of in-situ generated Cu(0) and Cu(I) species is of importance to determine the product profile of CO2RR. Nonetheless, it is very difficult to stabilize Cu(I) under operando conditions. The use of chronoamperometry at a fix potential drastically altered the chemical state of electrocatalysts due to the reduction of Cu(I) to Cu(0) [79]. Recently, pulsed electrocatalysis was proposed to improve the CO2RR by tuning the oxidation state of Cu [80,81]. Roldan Cuenya and co-workers applied an altered voltage program: a brief pulse at an anodic potential (E a = 0 ∼ 0.8 V, t a = 1 s) was followed by a cathodic pulse with different lengths (t c) at a potential typically used for CO2RR (E c = −1.0 V), repeating this sequence for 1 hour [75]. By properly choosing the anodic E a, Cu(I) with a varied content was continuously regenerated withstanding the CO2RR pulse, leading to the significant enhancement of C2+ products. It’s interesting that the increased ethanol FE could be correlated to the coexistence of Cu(I) and Cu(0), whereas the ethylene yield was determined by the length of the Cu(100) terraces. To further uncover the dynamic valence changes of Cu in pulsed CO2 electrolysis, the mismatch in time-scale of acquiring spectrum should be noticed. The acquiring time of conventional XAS, ambient pressure XPS and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS) is approximately dozens of minutes [71], however the chemical state of Cu could quickly reach a steady state in CO2RR of a few minutes [77]. Chen and co-workers developed an operando seconds-resolved XAS (Fig. 9 a) that provided a time-scale of few seconds to reveal the dominated factor on OD-Cu [79]. The model catalyst could reach a steady chemical state of half-Cu(0)-and-half-Cu(I) (Fig. 9b), which helped for producing C2H5OH. According to their theoretical analysis, a surface consisting of Cu(0)-Cu(I) ensembles were beneficial for two *CO coupled asymmetrically. Bader charge analysis (Fig. 9c) also suggested that this ensemble stabilized the asymmetrical OCCO intermediate through benign electrostatic interactions, in which the highly polar OCCO [(O(1)C(1))0.50+(C(2)O(2))1.68-] was stabilized by the Cu(0)/Cu(I). OH species at the boundary of Cu(0)/Cu(I) also enhanced ethanol formation (Fig. 9d), because their attractive electrostatic interaction with the carbonyl of hydrocarbon intermediates could protect the oxygen end from being protonated, as well as occupy the valence electron of carbon to avoid the formation of a C = C bond. In current mechanistic understanding, the formation of C2+ products is ascribed to the *CO dimerization on Cu sites, but this was recently challenged by the concerted shift in onset potentials of CH4 and EtOH on CuO derived Cu(0) dendrites [82]. It was proposed that adsorbed methyl species, *CH3, served as common intermediates of both CH3H and CH3CH2OH and possibly of other CH3-R products via a previously overlooked pathway at (110) steps adjacent to (100) terraces. Obiously, the clear identification on CO2RR pathways toward varied products is still challenging, mainly in virtue of the dynamic change of Cu surface at working potentials. 4.1.2 Reconstruction focusing on morphological changes In addition to in-situ reduction discussed above, the topological reconstruction of Cu-based electrocatalysts during CO2RR has also attracted interests. It should be pointed out that the morphological changes are inevitable along with the in-situ reduction of CuO x . A rougher surface was emphasized for OD-Cu electrocatalysts, because the reduction of CuO x and oxygen loss in the lattices could bring about more uncoordinated sites that controlled the dissociation barrier of CO2 [83,84]. Strasser and co-workers reported on 2D CuO nanosheets with high C2+ product selectivity in gas diffusion electrodes at industrially relevant currents and neutral pH [82]. The (001)-orientated nanosheets evolved into highly branched Cu(0) dendrites that were the dominant morphology under working conditions. Sargent and co-workers found in-situ formed high-curvature nanoneedles along with the electro-redeposition of Cu2(OH)3Cl favored C2+ production [85]. A catalytic trend was obviously correlated with higher curvature surfaces, beyond the influences made by the co-presence of Cu(I) and Cu(0). The sharp tips could improve bubble nucleation, stabilize cations and enable high local fields, all of which increased working current density and thereby promoted local pH, resulting in the limitation on the protonation of bound CO toward CH4 and the preference for dimerization. These findings underscore the importance of controlling morphology that even surpasses the effects by fine-tuning the oxidation state of Cu sometimes, but such topological reconstruction is self-evident in view of in-situ CuO x reduction. Next are the questions whether the metallic Cu can experience alteration and how the alternation works. Recently, the surface restructuring of Cu catalysts has been identified in both bulk and nanoparticle systems for CO2RR [17,86]. For instances, Gregoire and co-workers found that a polycrystalline Cu [Cu(pc)] electrode underwent stepwise surface reconstruction at a fix potential (-0.9 V vs. SHE) in Ar-purged 0.1 M KOH via electrochemical scanning tunneling microscopy (EC-STM) [86]. It converted to Cu(111) within the initial 30 min, and then to Cu(100) after another 30 min. No further transformations were observed after establishing Cu(100). This observation gives a reasonable explanation to the Cu(100)-like catalytic behavior of Cu(pc). Typically, surface reconstruction is driven by the thermodynamic demand for minimizing surface free energy [87], but a considerable kinetic barrier hinders this process at ambient conditions (Fig. 10 a). The rate of surface reconstruction depends on the mobility of surface atoms. As an inverse measure of surface-atom mobility, the cohesive energy of Cu (336 kJ mol−1) is comparatively smaller than that of Pt (546 kJ mol−1), which would not be an insurmountable hindrance at working potentials. The conversion of Cu(pc) to Cu(111) was consistent with the thermodynamic prediction, and indicated the applied potential surmounted the kinetic barrier that prohibited the reconstruction at ambient conditions. However, the second reconstruction, from Cu(111) to Cu(100), was conflict with the thermodynamics. The repulsive electrostatic forces at highly negative potentials was suggested to drive surface atoms to a less densely packed (100) structure. Similar reconstruction of Cu(pc) surface to Cu(100) was further identified in N2-purged 0.1 M KHCO3 [88]. The convergence toward the same (100) distribution regardless of pH or supporting electrolyte suggests that the reorganization is primarily driven by the negative potential applied, rather than the interactions with CO2 or its reaction intermediates. Such electrical deformations can be described by the theory of electromigration, in which current flow in micro- and nano-electronics causes the mass transport of solid metal matter [89]. A series of research further unravels the dependence of surface reconstruction on CO2RR and its derivatives, i.e., electrochemical effects. CO, a key intermediate in CO2RR, has been shown to aggravate the reconstruction under near-ambient pressure/temperature conditions [90]. Recently, Lee et al. characterized the near-surface structure of a Cu(pc) thin film (50 nm thickness) at a wide observation area (μm ∼ mm) under CO2RR conditions using in-situ grazing incidence X-ray absorption spectroscopy (GIXAS) and X-ray diffraction (GIXRD) [28]. Metallic Cu derived from the copper-oxide reduction prior to the onset of CO2RR was the only detectable phase during electrocatalysis. The succedent reconstruction from Cu(pc) to Cu(100) took place only in the presence of CO2, suggesting it was a CO-driven phenomenon. Such reconstruction turned more obvious when the applied potential became more negative, and the reconstructed surface partially persisted in the anodic steps. As pointed out by a theoretical research from Buonsanti and co-workers, the adsorption of either *H or *CO eventually varied the interface free energies of Cu (111), (100), and (110) facets, resulting in the distinct reconfigurations at CO2RR working potentials [27]. Therefore, the strong interactions between surface Cu atoms and CO2RR intermediates (e.g., *CO, *H, *OH, etc.) should be noted as the possible factor to overcome the kinetic barriers of surface reconstructions and even invert the thermodynamic relationship (Fig. 10b). Very recently, Klinkova and co-workers correlated the structural reconstruction of metal electrocatalysts in CO2RR to the both of electrical (electromigration) and electrochemical (atomic migration due to adsorbed reaction intermediates) effects [91]. Generally, in shaped cathodic electrocatalysts, nanoscale curvatures facing the anode form hotspots and facilitate surface reconstruction by intermediate-promoted atomic mobility. In the meanwhile, geometric constrictions in the cathodic nanostructures induce current-crowding hotspots. To minimize the hotspots, structural transformations via electromigration occurred as long as the surface atoms can break the bonds with their neighbors and overcome the energy barrier of migration. Although this conclusion was acquired from nanostructured Au and Pd, it still highlights the interplay of electrochemical and electrical effects that should be a matter of great concern for investigating Cu reconstruction in CO2RR. It is easy to deduce that small Cu nanoparticles with high surface energy are inclined to morphological changes at CO2RR conditions. Yang’s group reported that Cu nanoparticle (6.7 nm) underwent structural transformation into electrocatalytically active cube-like particles intermixed with smaller nanoparticles, coupled with the obviously enhanced selective electroconversion of CO2 to C2 ∼ C3 hydrocarbons and oxygenates [92]. Although the cause of structural transformation was still uncertain, the researchers pointed out the importance of electrically biased and chemically relevant conditions. Ethylene, ethanol, and n-propanol were the major C2–C3 products with an onset potential at −0.53 V (vs. RHE) and the FE reached 50% at only −0.75 V. When the above structure changes were minimal in control experiments, the catalytic conversion to C2–C3 products was accordingly prohibited, underscoring the in-situ formed active sites on cube-like particles. They further identified that bias-induced fusion or “electrochemical scrambling” of Cu nanoparticles created disordered structures in Cu ensembles that were active for C2+ formation at low overpotentials, around sevenfold enhancement over crystalline Cu [93]. It is noteworthy that the observation of Cu reconstruction depends on time-scale owing to the different transformation rate associated with particle size, applied potentials and other working conditions. Alivisatos and co-workers demonstrated both sintering and declustering of Cu nanoparticles occurring on different time scales, as particles first grew in size and later broke apart [94]. But the declustering was slower, presumably due to some stabilization effects by CO. By contrast, Buonsanti and co-workers discovered abnormal nanoclustering of Cu nanocubes followed by a coalescence process (Fig. 11 a) [27]. The general trend in Cu morphology consisted in an increase of the FE toward HER as the nanocluster population increased, in accordance with previous findings that smaller Cu with abundant un-coordinated sites favored HER at the expenses of CO2RR [95,96]. It’s pointed out by DFT calculations that the adsorption of either *H or *CO species on nanocrystal surface eventually induced the structural degradation. The interface free energies of (111), (100), and (110) including the effects of *H and *CO adsorption were calculated and shown in Fig. 11(b and c). For the clean surfaces, the interface energies at the potentials of zero charge were consistent with the well-documented thermodynamic stability γ 110 > γ 100 > γ 111 [87] and the reconstructed surfaces were found less stable than the initial ones. However, negative potentials induced *H/*CO adsorption, which in turn drove a drastic reduction of interface free energies for fully covered surfaces. The relative stability of these facets changed in the presence of adsorbates to γ 100 > γ 110 > γ 111. For both adsorbates, interface energies became negative between −0.4 and −0.5 V vs. RHE @pH = 7, except for H on Cu(100) (−0.68 V), indicating a strong driving force for Cu degradation. When the potential- and pH-dependent Wulff-shapes were derived from the interface free energies (including *H, *CO and co-adsorbed *H + *CO terminations), it was found that the cubicity of the polyhedron defined by (100), (110), and (111) facets decreased as the potential decreases (Fig. 11d). In other words, at more negative potentials Cu tends to non-cubic shapes because of smaller interface energies for adsorbate-covered (111) and (110). This potential-driven degradation highlights the key role of reaction-intermediates that were adsorbed on Cu facets and in turn varied the interface energies to some extent relying on applied potentials. It should be pointed out that the recently reported SRO owing to the presence of oxidant species may also contribute to the reconstruction [78]. In particular, when extensive CO2RR and HER proceed at Cu-based cathodes, the fast proton consumption will remarkably increases the [OH–] at electrode local surface, leading to a reoxidation-reduction cycle and thereby detectable structural changes. Vavra et al. employed a combination of in-situ TEM and operando XAS to disclose that oxide-dissolution followed by re-deposition, rather than coalescence, is the major factor responsible for the size increase and morphology change of Cu nanoparticles [97]. As demonstrated, Cu ions were generated by the chemical dissolution of the in-situ formed Cu2O phase under open circuit conditions, which were then redeposited onto the Cu nanoparticles while applying the reducing potential. Such dissolution-redeposition process was similar to Ostwald ripening, and the net reduction of surface free energy was the driving force for the reconstruction toward larger and spiny particles. Essentially, such SRO is associated with the surface binding of oxidants (e.g., *OH), and can be regarded as an extensive reconstruction of an electrochemical effect. The above examples confirm that the topological reconstruction of Cu bulk and nanoparticle systems can be ascribed to electrochemical and electrical effects in CO2RR. The interplay of them should be taken into account for the deformation mechanism of Cu facet-distribution and nanostructures. It is improper to directly correlate performance with initial topological structure of a Cu catalyst before electrolysis. For example, nanoclustering of bulky or nanostructured Cu can leads to a spiny surface with rich defects, essentially responsible for the favorable CO2RR toward C2+ products. 4.1.3 Boosting CO2RR via deliberate reconstruction The knowledge of Cu electrocatalyst reconstruction inspires in-situ electrochemical activation to boost CO2RR performance. Regarding the universal electrochemical reduction of high-valence-state copper and its contribution to boosting electrocatalytic performance, efforts have been devoted to directing the reduction toward deliberately designed chemical configurations of Cu surface. Pre-catalysts of CuO x , Cu x S, and Cu3N play a crucial role in the structure reconstruction, with the regard that breaking Cu-X (X = O, OH, S, N, etc.) bonds and releasing X elements under reduction potentials can induce distinct surface configurations [98 –101]. Copper oxides and hydroxides are the most extensively investigated precursors. But it is still challenging to control the surface atom arrangement owing to the random reconstruction of Cu. According to the theoretically evidenced facet dependence of the initial C–C coupling on Cu (100), Jiang et al. used a metal ion battery cycling method to synthesize Cu2O nanocubes with predominant Cu2O(100) facets, which were then reduced to polycrystalline Cu nanocubes with preferentially exposed Cu(100) [103]. The optimal Cu-nanocube catalyst (100-cycled) presented a six-fold improvement in the C2+ to C1 product ratio, in comparison with the pristine polished Cu foil, with a C2+ Faradaic efficiency of over 60% and a corresponding partial current density > 40 mA cm−2. Recently, a facet control over in-situ reduced Cu electrocatalysts was proposed by Gong and co-workers via modifying the structures of precursors [Cu(OH)2, CuO, and Cu2O, Fig. 12 a] [102]. The resulting catalysts were denoted as Cu(OH)2-D/Cu foil, CuO-D/Cu foil, and Cu2O-D/Cu foil, respectively. As identified by CVs (Fig. 12b) and GIXRD (Fig. 12c), Cu(OH)2-D exposed a relatively high density of stepped Cu(110) and Cu(100), in comparison with CuO-D and Cu2O-D. The assembly into Cu(210) and Cu(310) from Cu(110) and Cu(100) promoted CO adsorption and dimerization, leading to the improved activity to C2+ products (Fig. 12d). The Cu(OH)2-D/Cu foil further gained a higher C2+ FE of 87% in a flow-cell, and a solar conversion efficiency of 4.47% and 6.4% for C2H4 and C2+ products when coupled with a cheap Si solar cell. Copper sulfides are of interest as precursors to derive efficient Cu electrocatalysts, because they can provide a facile means to form and control defects/vacancies on the surface [104-106]. Ion vacancies that stabilize *CO, *OCCO, and *CH2CHO, and further promote their coupling are anticipated to surmount the great challenge of CO2RR remaining on producing C2 and C3 molecules [107,108]. Sargent and co-workers used DFT to examine the energetics of the hydrogenation of *CH2CHO to alcohol and ethylene on prinstin Cu, Cu with Cu vacancy, and Cu with Cu vacancy and subsurface S [99]. Results suggested that subsurface S atoms and Cu defects together shifted the balance in favour of EtOH by suppressing C2H4 production. They observed in-situ reduction of vacancy-rich Cu2S to a metallic Cu shell with abundant vacancies surrounding a Cu2S core (Cu2S-Cu-V) in CO2RR after initial running. These defective structures increased the alcohol/ethylene ratio more than sixfold in comparison with Cu nanoparticles in a H-cell, and achieved a C2+ alcohol (ethanol and propanol) production rate of 126 ± 5 mA cm−2 with a FE of 32 ± 1% in a flow-cell system. However, the FE of n-propanol is still low (8 ± 0.7%), owing to the insufficiency of stabilizing *C2 intermediates and further promoting C1–C2 coupling. It is hypothesized that an effective catalytic site for C3+ production should present a high density of negative charges or vacancies. Very recently, Zheng and co-workers demonstrated a double-sulfur vacancy (DSV) structure via lithium electrochemical tuning allowed for the stabilization of both *CO and a *C2 dimer (i.e., OCCO*), as well as subsequent coupling with a third *CO via CO–OCCO [109]. The DSV-rich CuS x catalyst exhibited a much-improved FE n-PrOH of 15.4 ± 1% at −1.05 V vs. RHE in 0.1 M KHCO3, corresponding to one of the highest CO2RR selectivities to n-propanol reported in H-cells to date. Using a flow cell with 1.0 M KOH, a high partial current density for n-propanol production was obtained as 9.9 mA cm−2 at −0.85 V vs. RHE, although the FE is accordingly reduced. Analogously, the in-situ reconstruction of copper sulfides (Cu 2-x S, CuS, etc.) might intrinsically contribute to the CO2RR behaviors in a series of previous reports that however either missed mornitoring in-situ formed active-sites or focusing other product (e.g., formic acid) rather than C2+ alcohols [110 –114]. Halogen anions usually possess strong interactions with Cu atoms, and thereby make detectable influences on the reduction and reconstruction of high-valence Cu. Sargent and co-workers presented the dissolution and redeposition of copper from a Cu2(OH)3Cl precursor to enhance copper catalysts with high-curvature nanostructures and abundant Cu(I) toward favorable C2+ production [85]. Yang and co-workers designed porous Cl-doped Cu via electrochemically activating CuOHFCl nanosheets, which afforded a high FE of C2+ products of 53.8 % at −1.0 V vs. RHE [115]. The residual-chlorine induced stable Cu(0)-Cu(I) sites that enabled a long-term stability (200 h) to generate C2+ products. In comparison, Han et al. proposed a quite difference interpretation to the enhancement of C2 selectivity on reconstructed Cu surface with the assistance of various halide anions [116]. The in-situ formed hierarchical pores via oxidation–reduction cycling were crucial for C2 products by increasing the local CO availability [117], which was distinct from the mechanism associated with lattice facets in other reports [102,118]. In addition, Arnaud et al., reported a electrochemical reconstruction for nanostructuring copper electrodes, using N, N’-ethylene-phenanthrolinium dibromide (1-Br2) as additive [119]. In the presence of 1-Br2, cubic nanostructures were observed through the surface of a copper electrode after CO2RR. The nanostructured Cu cubes by molecular additive showed the higher stability compared to the reconstructed Cu cubes, in which the selectivity up to 70% for C2+ products was observed for more than 40 h with negligible morphological change. Moreover, regarding the effect of *CO on Cu surface reconstruction, Zheng and co-workers recently introduced a CO-rich environment to construct defect-site-rich Cu (Cu-DS) catalysts from Cu2(CO)2Cl2 precursors (Fig. 13 a) [120]. A counterpart of Cu-C fabricated under an Ar environment was taken for comparison (Fig. 13b). As indicated by operando spectroscopies and theoretical calculations, the defect-site-rich surfaces enhanced local CO production, which thereby favored ethanol formation and suppressed ethylene formation. As a result, the Cu-DS achieved ∼70% FE toward C2+ alcohols in a H-cell system (Fig. 13c), a reversal of electrocatalytic behaviors of Cu-C (Fig. 13d). In flow electrolyzers, a C2+ alcohol partial current density of >100 mA cm−2 was obtained with a corresponding FE of 67% (Fig. 13e and f). Furthermore, using the Cu-DS catalyst in a membrane electrode assembly (MEA) electrolyzer, a stable C2+ alcohol production rate (∼ 500 mg cm−2) with FE of ∼60% was also obtained during a continuous operation of 30 h. As good examples, these interesting results opened up opportunities for improving CO2RR through directing the reconstruction of Cu surface. 4.2 Other electrocatalysts Metal elements, such as Ag, Au, Pd, Sn, Bi, and first-row VIII elements, are also active for CO2RR, showing differences in product selectivity as compared with Cu [121 –123]. For example, Ag and Au feature the production of CO and syngas (CO/H2), while Sn and Bi are efficient for the reduction to formic acid. Recent reports identified the in-situ reduction and the concomitant morphology changes of most metal-oxides during CO2RR using in-situ/operando techniques. The reconstructed surface with uncoordinated sites serves as the key to optimize the bindings with CO2RR intermediates toward efficient turnovers. Similar to Cu-based electrocatalyts, oxide derived Ag was evidenced with higher activity in comparison with electrodeposited Ag [125,126]. Smith and co-workers prepared highly active, stable, and selective Ag via the electroreduction of Ag2CO3 [127]. Very recently, Shao and co-workers identified the in-situ generation of rich defects of oxide-derived Ag during CO2RR using fast operando XAS that can acquire 120 sheets of spectra at the absorption edge per minute [124]. Once the cathodic potential was applied, the peak of the Ag–O bond (∼2.08 Å) in time-dependent EXAFS decreased quickly within the first four minutes and became indistinguishable at the sixth minute (Fig. 14 a). That of the Ag–Ag bond (∼2.86 Å) appeared at the fourth minute, and quickly grew from the sixth minute. These visible changes qualitatively confirmed the conversion from Ag2O to Ag. Accordingly, the quantitative comparison of the peak intensity of Ag–O and Ag–Ag (Fig. 14b) showed that the latter reached a stable value (∼1.19) after 11 min, visibly less than that for Ag foil reference (∼1.33), which indicated a lower coordination number of Ag atoms in in-situ reduced Ag. This judgement was further confirmed by the fitting EXAFS. The coordination number of the first shell of Ag–Ag bond increased with reaction time and finally reached a stable value of 7.2 after 30 min, obviously smaller than that of Ag foil reference (12). It’s demonstrated by DFT calculations that the adsorption of *COOH was strengthened on Ag atoms surrounding defect sites. Such catalyst exhibited a ∼ 100% FE and negligible degradation over a 120-hours test at −0.81 V vs. RHE in an H-cell reactor and a current density of ∼180 mA cm−2 at −1.0 V in a flow-cell reactor (Fig. 14c and d). This research highlights the functionality of lattice defects stemming from the fast reduction of oxide pre-catalysts. Referring to the above-mentioned Cu reconstruction, we expect more efforts devoted into the dynamic changes of various Ag-related precursors, which is helpful for understanding catalytic mechanisms and designing better catalysts. In comparison, the single dominant product of CO on Ag sites would make the relevant study relatively easier. Instead of CO, formic acid (formate) is another value-added product from the two-electron reduction of CO2. Bismuth (Bi) and tin (Sn) have attracted much attention due to the high selectivity for formate at low overpotentials [128 –130]. However, their in-situ reconstruction during CO2RR is not clear. Luo’s group prepared mesoporous Bi nanosheets through electrochemical transformation of (100)-facet exposed BiOI [131]. The in-situ morphological transformation led to disorders or defects that could alter the local electronic states and create under-coordinated sites with high activity [132]. Li and co-workers developed defective Bi nanotubes from β-Bi2O3 double-walled nanotubes under cathodic polarization [133]. When evaluated for CO2RR, the Bi nanotubes enabled highly active and selective formate production. Very recently, Qiao and co-workers uncovered the two-step reconstruction of Bi-MOFs (CAU-17) in CO2RR, i.e., electrolyte-mediated conversion of Bi-MOFs to Bi2O2CO3 and potential-driven further reduction to Bi [134]. Owing to the unsaturated Bi sites on surface, the intentionally reconstructed Bi exhibited excellent activity, selectivity, and durability for formate production. As for Sn-based electrocatalysts, Ye et al also confirmed the in-situ reduction of amorphous SnO x shell in Sn2.7Cu to a Sn/SnO x interface that optimized the binding with HCOO* and thereby promoted formic acid production [135]. Summarizing the work reviewed above, it is quite common that metal-oxides as pre-catalysts are in-situ reduced during CO2RR owing to highly negative potentials applied. The resulting surfaces with rich defects or unique nanostructures are responsible for apparent electrocatalysis, but the essentiality of microscopic kinetics deserves more concerns. Most of efforts have been devoted to the reconstruction of Cu-based electrocatalysts thanks to their capability for forming multiple-carbon products and the relatively high mobility of surface Cu atoms. Other elements, such as Ag, Bi, Sn, etc., have also demonstrated that the reconstruction from their oxides is feasible to achieve highly active CO2RR, but the insights into the dynamic changes of the as-reconstructed surface is still absent. Similar to Cu that suffers oxidation by oxidants in electrolytes, the in-situ reoxidation-reduction cycle of Ag, Bi and Sn should be considered to unravel electrocatalytic mechanism at atomic level. Meanwhile, the quantification of reconstruction rates and surface compositions can help to understand the correlation between reconstruction and intrinsic electrocatalytic activity. 5 Reconstruction in NRR Electrochemical reduction of N2 to NH3 on a heterogeneous surface is possible at room temperature and atmospheric pressure as long as a sufficient voltage is applied [136 –139]. Transition metal nitrides (TMNs) have been investigated as potential candidates for NRR [140,141]. Xu and co-workers demonstrated that vanadium nitride (VN) nanoparticles were active and selective [142]. The electrochemical NRR with 15N2 as the feed generated a mixture of 14NH3 and 15NH3, proving the involvement of surface N in catalytic turnovers. Ex-situ XPS revealed that multiple vanadium oxide, oxynitride and nitride species were present on the surface of the spent catalysts. The surface VN0.7O0.45 species was claimed as the active phase, and the conversion to VN was considered as the deactivation pathway. It’s pointed out that the presence of N in catalysts and the chemical stability of the nitride materials could spawn ambiguous results. Liu and co-workers discovered that the decomposition of tetragonal Mo2N accounted for the formation of ammonia [143], instead of catalyzing N2 reduction by nitrides. These results raise an urgent alert to the use of metal nitrides and even nitrogen containing materials in NRR. Many types of N-free nanomaterials have been developed for electrochemical N2 reduction to NH3, in which in-situ reduction of pre-catalysts was also observed. Bi-based electrocatalysts delivered excellent performance because of its tunable p-electron density and sluggish HER performance. Song and co-workers proposed the in-situ formation of S-doped Bi nanobelts via electrochemical reconstruction of Bi2S3 [144], via which the local electronic structure of Bi was extensively reconfigured. After electrochemical reduction, only slight Bi − S scattering can be observed as the shoulder peak of the Bi − Bi bond in EXAFS, implying the existence of defects caused by Bi − S bonds. These S-doped Bi nanobelts afforded a remarkable NH3 generation rate of 10.28 μg h−1 mg−1 and a FE of 10.48%. Ye and co-workers reported that Sn/SnS2 nanosheets gained a high ammonia yield of 23.8 µg h−1 mg−1 after in-situ electrochemical reduction, in which the amorphous Sn was considered as the active phase [145]. Present electrocatalysis is focusing on preparing NH3 through the reduction of pure N2, which is produced by the energy-intensive air-separation process. However, a vast amount of nitrate (NO3 –), another source of NH3, is unfortunately discharged into the surface water and underground aquifer, threatening human health [146]. The efficient reduction of nitrate to NH3 can not only cut down the related environmental disruption, but also produce value chemicals, which attracts extensive research interests [147]. Zhang and co-workers reported CuO nanowire arrays as an efficient cathodic electrocatalyst for nitrate reduction to NH3 [148]. 15N isotope labeling experiments identified that ammonia was originated from nitrate reduction. In-situ Raman and other ex-situ analysis revealed the electrochemical reduction from CuO to Cu/Cu2O during electrocatalysis, and confirmed the existence of electron transfer at the interface of Cu/Cu2O that served as the active phase. The above findings are analogical to that of CO2RR electrocatalysts, because the reduction is thermodynamically viable at highly negative working potentials. However, they deserve more attentions because the stability and reconstruction behaviors of electrocatalysts are usually omitted in previous research. N-containing materials, e.g., TMNs and even others produced from nitrate salts, should be double-checked to judge whether the NH3 come from the reconstruction of electrocatalysts. Typically, qualitative and quantitative 15N isotope labeling measurements are demanded [149]. Up to date, the reconstruction was only investigated in several electrocatalyst systems, the general reconstructing principles and the utilization to design better catalysts are still desired. 6 Conclusions and perspectives The recent progresses in understanding the in-situ reconstruction of electrocatalysts are summarized for cathodic reactions (Table 1 ). The origin of electrocatalyst reconstruction can be ascribed to the applied potentials and the strong interactions with reactants or intermediates. Identification on the refactoring processes and the subtle structure of in-situ formed species (namely, true catalysts) not only gives insights into the electrocatalytic mechanism at working states, but also inspires extensive efforts devoted into fine-tuning the microstructures of pre-catalysts (Fig. 15 ). For HER, the oxidation or reduction of electrocatalyst surface may vary the d-band center or electronic density, leading to effective modulation on the chemisorption of intermediates. Thus, regulating the reconstruction via changing working conditions, such as potentials, temperature, electrolytes, and so forth, is feasible to improve electrocatalytic performance. For CO2RR, the in-situ reduction of electrocatalysts is prevailing owing to the highly negative applied potentials. But SRO due to the oxidative species in electrolytes will induce a dynamic reoxidation-reduction cycle on electrocatalyst surface, resulting in the arrangement of atoms or clusters. Another change of surface topology due to the strong interactions with reaction intermediates at applied potentials also attracts attentions, which effectively vary the mobility of surface atoms and interface energy. Some efficient strategies have also been proposed to direct or control catalyst reconstruction, achieving the obvious enhancements of catalytic activity and durability. As for NRR, similar reconstruction due to in-situ reduction is also identified, which needs special attentions to make sure the real activity for catalyzing N2 reduction, rather than catalyst reconstruction/decomposition. As noticed, HER serves as the main side reaction of NRR and CO2RR reduction processes. Therefore, the reconstruction in the latter two systems can be also contributed by the HER–induced reconstruction. However, the presence of *CO in CO2RR can bring about further impact on the reconstruction owing to the strong adsorption on catalyst surface. Owing to the more negative working potentials and stronger bindings of intermediates, the reconstruction of catalysts in CO2RR and NRR is relatively more extensive in comparison with that in HER. In addition, electrocatalysis under non-aqueous electrolytes is another hotspot for electrochemical synthesis [150,151], and deserves special attentions for electrocatalyst reconstruction because various organic or ionic liquid electrolytes may activate or passivate the surface of electrodes. It’s expected to acquire new understanding on cathodic electrocatalyst reconstruction from non-aqueous electrocatalysis, which can compensate the current knowledge mostly coming from aqueous systems. It’s noteworthy that in-situ reconstruction of electrocatalysts/electrodes is prevailing in other new energy storage/conversion systems. For example, ORR is a significant cathodic reaction in H2-O2 and metal-O2 fuel cells, whose catalyst reconstruction has been extensively investigated in a series of previous review articles [12,152,153]. Very recently, dynamic behavior of single-atom M−N−C (M = Cu, Fe, etc.) catalysts in ORR was unraveled by combining operando XAS and FT-IR with theoretical calculations [154-156], which provided a new understanding of the working mechanism of M−N−C catalysts and guided the design of more efficient low-cost catalysts. In the meanwhile, in-situ reconstruction of electrodes in lithium-sulfur batteries and lithium-air batteries is critical for electrochemical performance, as the formation of dendrite on the surface of metal anodes induces the rupture and reconstruction of solid electrolyte interphase (SEI), likely accelerating the excessive consumption of electrolyte and the formation of dead metals [157,158]. The relevant attentions should be paid onto the dynamic changes of electrodes when their electrochemical processes and mechanisms are investigated, however they are out of the scope of this review. The knowledge of electrocatalyst reconstruction in HER, CO2RR and NRR further enlightens the exploration of high performance electrocatalysts via controlling or directing the dynamic changes of pre-catalysts. As a proof of this concept, efforts were devoted to in-situ deriving defective Cu nanograins from high-valence Cu species during CO2RR, which were highly active for C2+ products. The presence of halogen anions (e.g., Cl-, Br- and I-) and CO molecules that possess strong bindings with surface Cu atoms can result in rich defects in a control manner to boost the production of C2+ olefins and alcohols [115,120]. Meanwhile, the pre-reduction potentials are also important for achieving reactive surface with engineered structures. Dealing with a Cu(OH)2 precursor, Hwang and co-workers found that the initial reduction conditions applied were critical for selective and stable ethylene production [68], becuase they altered the chemical states. In particular, a highly negative reduction potential produced a catalyst that possessed mixed oxidized Cu species along with high oxygen content, and maintained long-term stability for the selective production of ethylene over methane. When a mild reduction condition was applied, the mixed states disappeared on the catalyst that became more favorable to CH4 formation after few hours. These results showed the corelation between the durability of ethylene production and Cu − O containing surface, consistent with the favored coulping of *CO on mixed-valenced Cu sites [159 –161]. Yet, in-depth studies are still desired to shed more light on the atomic-scale effects and overall real-life feasibility of these reconstructed catalysts. To this end, we suggest that future efforts should be devoted to the following topics (Fig. 16 ). Firstly, it’s necessary to establish a combination of various in-situ/operando techniques with complementary aspects to systematically track the dynamic structure and identify the real active species [9,23]. As discussed above, in-situ or operando approaches, e.g., XRD, XAS, XPS, Raman, SECM, EC-STM, etc., have been employed to monitor the surface reconstruction of electrocatalysts in HER, CO2RR and NRR [162,163], but in most cases, they were solely used for investigations. It should be noted that each technique has a distinct function due to its specific probing mechanism and corresponding application scope [10]. It is difficult to achieve a comprehensive understanding through a single in-situ/operando approach only. For example, XRD is usually taken to analyze the crystal structure of a solid material, but is invalid for the in-situ generation of amorphous surface oxides on solid surface or interfaces, which can be easily tracked by Raman or FT-IR techniques. Moreover, the time-resolution of acquiring spectrum is another key factor for capturing surface reconstruction. Regarding the fast evolution of metal centers to their steady state in a few minutes, a time-resolved identification is highly desired. Therefore, the rational combination of techniques with various functions, probing regions (solid, interface, or liquid), time-resolution, etc., should be taken in future investigations. As exemplified, Chen and co-workers identified the dynamic reoxidation/reduction-driven atomic interdiffusion of Ag into Cu bulks when a pre-catalyst of Cu/Ag nanowires was implemented for CO2RR, via a combination of in-situ characterizations including Raman, XANES, EXAFS, and GAXS [78]. To accommodate the match in time-scale between acquiring spectra and catalyst reconstruction, they further utilized quick XAS with a small X-ray incident angle to realize the seconds-resolved near-surface investigations of Cu electrodes [79]. Secondly, theoretical interpretation and prediction for the in-situ reconstruction of electrocatalysts are required. There is still no systematic research on the evolution of catalysts in electrocatalysis. Theoretical calculations are aimed to discuss the relationship between the changes and surface chemistry, instead of “the catalysts’ self-changing”. The ultimate goal is to establish a systematic theory to interpret the reconstruction processes of pre-catalysts, and further to predict the transformation toward working states. This is significant for exploiting new catalysts with high activity, selectivity and long-term stability. By controlling calculation conditions and optimizing reaction parameters, the newly-developed machine learning can simulate the entire reaction process and predict the dynamic evolutions, inferring the reconstruction mechanisms from theoretical analysis [164]. Future investigation by combining in-situ experiments and machine learning is a critical issue, which is expected to greatly improve research efficiency [30,165,166]. Thirdly, techniques could be designed to directly observe the chemical configurations of reaction intermediates adsorbed on in-situ generated active sites. This can bridge the gap between catalytic performance and surface reconstruction under an experimental condition, providing atomic-level insights into the dynamic processes of intermediate formation and conversion. The interface-sensitive Raman and FT-IR measurements are suitable for this purpose [23], and they have been utilized in the study of CO2RR and HER. However, there are still challenges in their sensitivity, anti-interference ability, and repeatability. Further efforts should be devoted to the rational design of working setups. Finally, new electrocatalytic routes should be developed along with the gradually deepened understanding of catalyst reconstruction at cathodes. On the one hand, new electrochemical protocols are exploited to exert in-situ generated surface for efficient electrocatalysis. In comparison with extensively-investigated cathodic activation, the newly-developed pulse electocatalysis enables the merits of fresh surface, controlled valence states, and variable Helmholtz double-layers for efficient CO2RR [167,168]. This new route is anticipated for the further use in other cathodic electrocatalysis, e.g., HER, NRR, etc. On the other hand, available catalyst reconstructions in a larger variety of electrocatalytic reactions can bring new opportunities toward the boosted catalytic efficiency and in-depth understanding on mechanisms. Electrochemical refinery of various chemicals [169 –171], such as electrocatalytic hydrogenation, hydrogenolysis, C-N formation, etc., may undergo the similar reconstructions of working catalysts owing to quite negative potentials, which are not understood yet at the current stage. Tao, Y. Wu, Z. Wu, B. Shang, C. Rooney, H. Wang, J. Energy Chem. 65 (2022) 367-370. Wenbiao Zhang is a doctoral student of chemistry at Jinan University, Guangzhou, China. He received his B.S. degree in 2016 and master degree in 2019 from Jinan University under the supervision of Prof. Qingsheng Gao. His research focuses on electrocatalytic energy conversion. Yang Yang received PhD degree at Jinan University under the supervision of Prof. Qingsheng Gao. His research focuses on Pd-based nanostructrues used for electro-oxidation of small molecules and electrochemical biosensing. He is currently working at Shenzhen University as a post-doctor researcher. Yi Tang is a professor of chemistry in Fudan University. He received his BSc degree of chemistry in 1985 and his PhD degree of physical chemistry in 1990 from Fudan University. His research interests have been with zeolite synthesis, characterization, modification and application in catalysis. He is now mainly working in the fields of synthesis, assembly and functionalization of noble-metal-free electrocatalysts and nanozeolite. Qingsheng Gao is a professor of chemistry at Jinan University, Guangzhou, China. He received his B.S. degree in 2005 and Ph.D. degree in 2010 from Fudan University. Then, he carried out his postdoctoral research in the Max-Planck Institute for Colloids and Interfaces in Germany. His current research interests focus on the development of noble-metal-free nanostructures used in catalysis and energy conversion.

coredata.dc:description: Cathodic electrocatalytic reactions, such as hydrogen evolution and CO2/N2 reduction, are the key processes that store intermittent electricity into stable chemical energy. Although a great progress has been made to boost activity and selectivity via elaborative catalyst design, the structure–property relationships have not been sufficiently understood in the context of surface reconfiguration under working conditions. Recent efforts devoted to tracking dynamic evolution of electrocatalysts using in-situ and/or operando techniques gave new insights into the real structure and working mechanism of active sites, and provided principles to design better catalysts. The achievement of cathodic electrocatalysts in this subject is herein summarized, focusing on the correlations between reconstructed surface and electrocatalytic performance. Briefly, the thermodynamics of reconstruction at cathodes is discussed at first, and then the representative progresses in H2 evolution and CO2/N2 reduction are introduced in sequence to acquire insights into electrochemical processes on in-situ reconfigured surfaces or interfaces. Finally, a perspective is offered to guide future investigations. This review is anticipated to shed some new light on in-depth understanding cathodic electrocatalysis and exploiting prominent electrocatalysts.
